message_1:
Suppose there are ten students in a class and the scores of those students on two tests, Test 1 and Test 2, are given in the table below. Calculate the correlation coefficient between the scores of Test 1 and Test 2.

| Student | Test 1 Score | Test 2 Score |
| ------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| 1       | 78          | 85          |
| 2       | 92          | 91          |
| 3       | 86          | 89          |
| 4       | 69          | 72          |
| 5       | 97          | 98          |
| 6       | 83          | 81          |
| 7       | 75          | 79          |
| 8       | 80          | 83          |
| 9       | 89          | 87          |
| 10      | 91          | 92          |
message_2:
To calculate the correlation coefficient (Pearson's r) between the scores of Test 1 and Test 2, we will use the following formula:

r = Σ[(xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ)] / √[Σ(xi - x̄)² * Σ(yi - ȳ)²]

where xi and yi are the individual test scores, x̄ is the mean of Test 1 scores, and ȳ is the mean of Test 2 scores.

First, let's calculate the mean of Test 1 and Test 2 scores:

x̄ = (78 + 92 + 86 + 69 + 97 + 83 + 75 + 80 + 89 + 91) / 10 = 840 / 10 = 84
ȳ = (85 + 91 + 89 + 72 + 98 + 81 + 79 + 83 + 87 + 92) / 10 = 857 / 10 = 85.7

Now, let's calculate the numerator and denominator of the formula:

Numerator: Σ[(xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ)]
Denominator: √[Σ(xi - x̄)² * Σ(yi - ȳ)²]

For each student, we will calculate (xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ), (xi - x̄)², and (yi - ȳ)²:

| Student | (xi - x̄) | (yi - ȳ) | (xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ) | (xi - x̄)² | (yi - ȳ)² |
| ------- | ------- | ------- | --------------- | ------- | ------- |
| 1       | -6       | -0.7     | 4.2             | 36      | 0.49    |
| 2       | 8        | 5.3      | 42.4            | 64      | 28.09   |
| 3       | 2        | 3.3      | 6.6             | 4       | 10.89   |
| 4       | -15      | -13.7    | 205.5           | 225     | 187.69  |
| 5       | 13       | 12.3     | 159.9           | 169     | 151.29  |
| 6       | -1       | -4.7     | 4.7             | 1       | 22.09   |
| 7       | -9       | -6.7     | 60.3            | 81      | 44.89   |
| 8       | -4       | -2.7     | 10.8            | 16      | 7.29    |
| 9       | 5        | 1.3      | 6.5             | 25      | 1.69    |
| 10      | 7        | 6.3      | 44.1            | 49      | 39.69   |

Now, let's sum up the values in the last three columns:

Σ[(xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ)] = 4.2 + 42.4 + 6.6 + 205.5 + 159.9 + 4.7 + 60.3 + 10.8 + 6.5 + 44.1 = 544.5
Σ(xi - x̄)² = 36 + 64 + 4 + 225 + 169 + 1 + 81 + 16 + 25 + 49 = 670
Σ(yi - ȳ)² = 0.49 + 28.09 + 10.89 + 187.69 + 151.29 + 22.09 + 44.89 + 7.29 + 1.69 + 39.69 = 493.31

Now, we can calculate the correlation coefficient:

r = 544.5 / √(670 * 493.31) ≈ 544.5 / √(330319.7) ≈ 544.5 / 574.73 ≈ 0.947

The correlation coefficient between the scores of Test 1 and Test 2 is approximately 0.947, which indicates a strong positive correlation between the two test scores.
